instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.ADAPTER_EN: What is ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.C1802: What is C1802? Capacitor to ground on PCH_SRTCRST_L on machines from 2009-2012, PCH_SRTCRST_L needs to be high for PCH to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.C1803: What is C1803? Capacitor to ground on RTC_RESET_L on machines from 2009-2012, RTC_RESET_L needs to be high for system to not be in RTC reset mode, this capacitor can become corroded or leaky and result in this signal being pulled low. .
definitions.ADPATER_EN: What is ADPATER_EN? This is a typo of SMC_ADAPTER_EN When you see ADPATER_EN, assume they meant to type SMC_ADAPTER_EN.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message:
This Mac draws 0.019-0.025 Amps at 16.5V
Green light on charger but no power. Does not respond to SMC reset.
In measuring rails I got to <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> which fluctuated between 3.8 and 5V.
Replaced <CHIP>U7941</CHIP> and <CHIP>U7200</CHIP>. Now a consistent 5V on <SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>. Still no power though.
Moving down the rails I got no <SIGNAL>PP5V_SUS</SIGNAL>.
<CAPACITOR>C1802</CAPACITOR> and <CAPACITOR>C1803</CAPACITOR> 3.3V
<SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> at <RESISTOR>R5085</RESISTOR> 0V

Very small patches of corrosion were found on a few probe points in the machine but no corrosion was spotted on any components.

Where should I go from here?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: PPBUS voltage? 60W charger or higher? <SIGNAL>ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> should of course be present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: PPBUS = 12.6V. Charger cable connected to bench PSU set to 16.5V 3.65A

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: It depends on what charger cable you are using. The ID is in the tip so if you use some 45W one from an air the board won't power on. Does it work from a charged battery?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: Ah I see what you mean. I use 85W tips to use with the PSU. Only other battery I have is empty from a machine that "doesn't recognize battery" so hardly reliable. Tried it anyway, it's not charging as the Mac still only pulls about 0.020 Amps.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: It will not charge as <SIGNAL>ADPATER_EN</SIGNAL> is not high. The machine is not seeing the adapter or there is something wrong with the SMC.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: Reflowed the SMC, no change. Any other way to narrow down if this is the SMC at fault or something else?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> green light no power
threads.message: I would first try if this boots from a battery with a charge. After that SMC change is next.
